awd_titl_txt: SCC-RCN: Smart Civic Engagement in Rapidly Urbanizing Regions
awd_abstract_narration:
Solutions for large-scale problems like stormwater management in urbanizing regions require input from a variety of stakeholders and coordination between nearby cities and towns. However, institutional barriers commonly prevent open discussion for collaborative decision-making. The team envisions a new way to enhance smart connections among communities and break down barriers across geographic space, levels of governance, and types of expertise: a collaborative platform for knowledge-sharing that suits diverse stakeholder needs, a mutually developed environment called TomorrowNow. This Research Collaboration Network (RCN) will unite regional stakeholders from government, industry, academia, watershed associations, and other community groups to guide the development of TomorrowNow, advancing the contribution of diverse perspectives to stormwater management and decision-making. The publicly available, multi-userenvironment conceptualized by the RCN will be transformative for crowdsourcing the opinions of a wide range of stakeholders and local residents in the Triangle region of North Carolina. Residents will be able to explore and visualize intervention strategies in the very places where they live and work, to inform management decisions regarding stormwater and improve quality of life. Ultimately, the online game conceptualized by the RCN will not only provide an engaging, intuitive platform in the Triangle, but will serve as a model to empower smart and connected communities elsewhere.


This RCN will collaboratively explore whether multi-user, web-based collaborative decision making using real data and scientific models to show the connectedness of locations could increase equitable participation in local decision-making, elevating the voices of underprivileged groups and diverse perspectives. The RCN will unite researchers and stakeholders to plan the design of a collaborative decision environment, TomorrowNow, which enables people to interact with spatially explicit models of urbanization and associated changes to stormwater hydrology (quantity) and biogeochemistry (quality), problems of increasing concern across urbanizing regions in the US. The RCN will convene leaders from local and regional governments, non-governmental organizations, and research teams specializing in natural, social, and computer sciences in the Research Triangle region of North Carolina; these leaders will collaboratively identify needs and approaches for improving inclusive participation and allowing a wider range of stakeholders to explore and visualize intervention strategies in the places where they live and work. Development of the network will advance the science of co-producing actionable solutions among researchers, policymakers, and residents, as well as identify research directions that advance new genres of urbanization and stormwater models (hydrologic and biogeochemical) needed to underlie the user-friendly interface of a serious game.  TomorrowNow  will enable communities connected by shared water networks (and their associated problems of stormwater runoff, surface water contamination, and groundwater quantity/quality) to collaboratively design alternative futures that optimize management of those water networks. The input of diverse communities will be collected via surveys, semi-structured interviews, panels, discussions during in-person workshops and symposia, and through discussion threads in an open-source online community.

por.por_cntn:
a. Project Outcomes

 Researchers from four universities in the Triangle Region of North Carolina came together to create a Research Coordination Network of over thirty partners from government agencies, academic institutions, non-profits, and industry. Their aim was to begin finding out whether and how serious games can help broaden cooperation and decision-making in stormwater management.

The research team held two workshops with partners to better understand barriers to stormwater management and to determine how different groups think about stormwater management issues in the Triangle, so that multiple perspectives could be incorporated into the design of a serious game prototype called TomorrowNow.

The team learned that spatial scale??from street-level to neighborhood to multi-city region??affects how government employees and academic researchers think about stormwater problems and solutions. These results are directly affecting the choice of data and models used in the TomorrowNow prototype. The new collaborations made possible through the Research Coordination Network are also transforming relationships between academics and government decision-makers to better serve the needs of constituents in the Triangle.

Beyond the development of the TomorrowNow prototype, several other new projects emerged from the formation of the Research Coordination Network:

(1) To better characterize stormwater flow in local cities and towns, researchers developed stormwater flow models with very high resolution (one meter) to pinpoint how water flows over properties, streets, and other urban infrastructure and to identify storm drains that are well placed versus those that are poorly placed or otherwise ineffective; the model was demonstrated to officials from the Town of Cary for potential use in their town.

(2) In rapid response to the COVID-19 pandemic, researchers developed a way to model the flow of wastewater through the Triangle Region?s sewer network, supporting community surveillance of SARS-CoV-2 in urban wastewater systems throughout the area.

(3) To address local residents? flooding concerns, researchers collected data before and during three stages of construction of new urban development in the Walnut Creek Watershed and will use those data, as well as data from new stream gauges in the Town of Cary, to determine if stormwater control measures at the construction site are adequate to prevent downstream flooding. 

(4) To address residents? concerns about the quality of drinking water, researchers created a new tool to improve models that track pollution from stormwater runoff for the two largest water supply reservoirs in the Triangle??Jordan Lake and Falls Lake.

 

b. Publications (automatically added) and other products (e.g., collections, data sets, software, educational materials)

- Work supported by the Research Coordination Network advanced the development of the open-source FUTure Urban-Regional Environment Simulation (FUTURES) land change model and release of FUTURES v2.0; FUTURES is one of the few land change models developed to explicitly capture the spatial structure of development. Details can be found at https://github.com/ncsu-landscape-dynamics/GRASS_FUTURES.

- Work supported by the Research Coordination Network advanced the development of the open-source Tangible Landscape system and release of Tangible Landscape v1.0; Tangible Landscape combines a physical model of a landscape with a geographic information system (GIS) and permits people of all skill levels to explore and control complex geospatial models. Details can be found at https://tangible-landscape.github.io.

-  An open-source fuzzy cognitive mapping library was updated from an existing project and used to analyze stakeholder data. The repository can be found at https://github.com/tomorrownow/PyFCM. 

 - Development began on the creation of the backend application programming interface (API) that will serve as the core of TomorrowNow, allowing scientific models such as urban growth (e.g., FUTURES [FUTure Urban-Regional Environment Simulation]), surface water runoff (e.g., SIMWE [SIMulate Water Erosion]) and inundation flooding (e.g., HAND [Height Above Nearest Drainage]) to interact with one another and with stakeholders via an online platform. The current status of the project can be tracked on GitHub at https://github.com/tomorrownow/TomorrowNowApp. 

- To address local residents? concerns about the quality of drinking water, a database and tool were developed to improve modeling nutrient transport in runoff across space and time. The data were derived from 10-meter digital elevation models (DEM) and land cover data (e.g., NWALT [National Water-Quality Assessment (NAWQA) Wall-to-Wall Anthropogenic Land Use Trends]).

 

c. Anticipated Publications and/or any other info that would be of interest to the public

- Researchers developed the interactive TomorrowNow Challenge Explorer (https://cwhite911.github.io/hydro-grass-viz/#16/35.775697/-78.636525/-80/59) to collect stakeholder input about wicked stormwater problems in the Triangle Region of NC and enable stakeholders to explore the problems identified by others. The Challenge Explorer was framed as a game that uses a real geospatial stormwater flow model and real outputs from an inundation (flooding) model.
